level.text: DYRS shall hold youth, who have entered into a Community Release Agreement, accountable for behavior contrary to public safety or the terms of the Community Release Agreement.

DYRS shall initiate a review of the youth’s community placement status within three (3) business days and shall convene a Community Status Review Hearing when DYRS becomes aware that a committed youth has been charged for the commission, attempted commission, or conspiracy to commit any of the following:
Homicide, attempted homicide, or assault with intent to commit homicide;
Sexual abuse in the 1st or 2nd degree, forcible rape, attempted forcible rape, assault with intent to commit forcible rape, or sodomy;
Robbery while armed, attempted robbery while armed, robbery, attempted robbery, assault with intent to commit robbery while armed;
Carjacking;
Armed Carjacking;
Burglary;
Kidnapping;
Arson;
Assault with intent to kill;
Malicious disfigurement;
Manslaughter;
Mayhem; or
Murder.
DYRS shall initiate a review of the youth’s community status within three (3) business days and may convene a Community Status Review Hearing if:
DYRS becomes aware that a youth has violated two or more terms of their Community Release Agreement;
DYRS becomes aware that a youth has violated a term of their Community Release Agreement at least twice;
DYRS becomes aware that a youth has unjustifiably absconded from the placement specified in the Community Release Agreement; or
DYRS Case Worker determines, based upon on a complete evaluation of the youth’s performance under the Community Release Agreement, that he or she should initiate the Community Status Review process.
Juveniles who violate twice or more any of the terms of their release agreement (not necessarily the same terms) may be subject to the same revocation process.
The social service worker shall determine, based on a complete evaluation of the child’s performance under the release agreement, whether to start the revocation process.
